# Loops {#sec-day2-loops}

There are two common types of loops in programming:

1.  *For* loops
2.  *While* loops

These are consistent with other programming languages. Below are some examples to illustrate the required *R* syntax.

## For Loops

The general structure of the syntax is:

`for (indicator in iterable){ ... }`

where the indicator is a variable which iterates through an object which is *iterable*. Therefore, indicator can be anything.




::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
a <- 1:10

sum = 0 
for (i in a){
  sum = sum + i
}
print(sum)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 55
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
sentence <- "hello world and some other words"
anIterable <- strsplit(sentence, " ")
for (word in anIterable){
  print(word)
}
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] "hello" "world" "and"   "some"  "other" "words"
```


:::
:::




We can even have nested for loops, which is when we have a for loop within another for loop!

## While Loops

The general structure of the syntax is:

`While (condition) { ... }`

where the condition is a Boolean (`TRUE` or `FALSE`). It could be the result of many conditions combined with logical operators. This loop will continue until this condition is false.




::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
max = 10
x <- 0; i <- 0
while(x <= max){
  i <- i + 1
  x <- x + 2 * i 
}
x
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
[1] 12
```


:::
:::
